item.title: Internal: Use Dubsplat to Identify Reverse Proxy Setup Issues
item.description:
If you are helping a customer to set up a Hub on a subdirectory ("Hubs on Dubs"), this guide describes how to troubleshoot the customer's reverse proxy setup by using the Dubsplat debugging tool.

 

Before You Begin

  • This document is for internal use only. Please do not share it with customers or anyone else outside of Uberflip.
  • This guide is intended for Uberflippers who are helping a customer to set up a custom domain on a subdirectory. In most cases, this would be a CSM, an Onboarding Specialist, or a Solutions Engineer.
  • This guide is intended to complement the Hubs on Subdirectories setup guide, which you can find here.

 

A Quick Dubsplat Primer

What is Dubsplat?

Dubsplat is a debugging tool. It looks for common problems in Hubs that are served over a reverse proxy. Hubs that use a subdirectory custom domain (i.e. "Hubs on Dubs") must use a reverse proxy, so Dubsplat is primarily intended for this type of Hub. However, it will also work on Hubs that use a regular subdomain custom domain, or the default co-branded sub-domain.

How Does Dubsplat Work?

When a browser visits a Hub, it sends an HTTP request message to the Hub, and the Hub sends back a response message with the requested content. The main difference with a Hubs on Dubs Hub is that these messages need to pass through a proxy server that sits between the browser and the Hub.

Ideally, we want the proxy to pass the messages between the browser and the Hub unchanged. Most Hubs on Dubs issues happen when the proxy makes changes to these messages, so Dubsplat works by identifying if (and how) this is happening.

Dubsplat compares the request and response messages before and after they pass through the proxy, looking for differences. It does this by first sending requests to the Hub and receiving the returning responses, just like a normal browser. This forms the baseline: Dubsplat now knows what both the original request messages and the response messages from the server looked like.

To make a comparison, Dubsplat also needs to know what the server actually received, and what it sent back. To get this information, Dubsplat sends its requests to a special @debugging endpoint that exists in every Hub.

Whenever the @debugging endpoint receives a request, it simply sends back a packet of data (a JSON object) that tells Dubsplat what the request message looked like when it arrived in the Hub, and what the Hub sent back in the response message:

Dubsplat now knows what it sent and what the Hub actually received; and what the Hub sent back and what Dubsplat actually received. If there are any discrepancies, we can assume that they were likely caused the reverse proxy, so Dubsplat flags them as potential issues with the way the reverse proxy is set up.

Tip

If you want, you can access the @debugging endpoint manually — it's always located in the root directory of a subdomain Hub, or the subdirectory of a Hubs on Dubs Hub:

  • https://hub.uberflip.com/@debugging

  • https://www.uberflip.com/culture/@debugging

Requesting this endpoint in your browser will display the JSON object that it returns (Firefox will format this nicely; other browsers will just return the raw data). You can see what this looks like in the screenshot above.

The same information is actually also included in Uberflip's error pages, such as our 404 page. The difference is that, on these pages, it's part of the HTML of the page, rather than a JSON object. This difference in format helps Dubsplat to figure out if a request is reaching Uberflip, but is being sent to an error page rather than an actual Hub.

How Does Dubsplat Help to Identify Reverse Proxy Issues?

HTTP request and response messages mainly consist of a list of parameters (header fields) and values. When we talk about a reverse proxy changing these messages, this generally means that it is modifying a value, or simply deleting a parameter altogether.

If the reverse proxy is altering any parameter, there is usually a corresponding setting in the reverse proxy that controls this behaviour. Troubleshooting the reverse proxy configuration is therefore a matter of figuring out exactly what is being changed, then identifying the setting responsible and adjusting it.

Dubsplat helps with this by flagging specific instances where parameters have been changed or are missing, with a particular focus on parameters that will either break Hub functionality or make the entire Hub inaccessible. Armed with this information, you can then help the customer identify the root cause (i.e. the corresponding setting), allowing them to make the necessary changes. As a bonus, Dubsplat is also able to flag miscellaneous configuration issues, such as problems with SSL or DNS.

 

Use Dubsplat to Troubleshoot a Hub

  • You can use Dubsplat with any Hub — all you need is the Hub's main URL.
  • As noted above, Dubsplat is primarily intended for Hubs on subdirectory custom domains, and will be most useful when used with this type of Hub.
  • While you can use Dubsplat at any time, it is mainly designed to test reverse proxy setups, so it is best used once the customer has fully set up their reverse proxy. The appropriate time to use this tool is indicated in the Hubs on Subdirectories setup guide.

Step 1: Run a Test

  1. To begin, open Dubsplat by visiting this URL: https://dubsplat.herokuapp.com/
  2. Enter the URL for the Hub you want to test into the URL field. This must be the URL for the homepage of the Hub, and must also include the protocol (http/https). For example:
    • Incorrect: www.customer.com/hub/
    • Correct: https://www.customer.com/hub/
  3. Click the Test button to begin the test.
  4. Dubsplat will run the test, and will return a results page. This should only take a few seconds.

Step 2: Review Results & Advise Customer

When the test has completed, Dubsplat will display the results page. This page will contain one or more messages, and each message corresponds to a specific issue that Dubsplat has identified. These messages point out problems which require action by the customer to resolve.

There are four types of message:

  • Success: This message will appear by itself, and indicates that Dubsplat did not find problems in any of the areas it is able to test. This means the reverse proxy is most likely set up correctly.
  • Testing Failed: These messages will appear when Dubsplat was unable to connect, and therefore could not complete testing.
  • Warning: These messages indicate that Dubsplat connected to the specified URL, but something went wrong and Dubsplat could not identify the exact problem.
  • Error: Messages of this type signal that Dubsplat identified a specific problem with the reverse proxy setup (reverse proxy is making an unwanted change).

Each message (except for the Success message) contains:

  • A brief description of the problem that Dubsplat identified
  • An explanation of what this means, including what Dubsplat tried to test, how it went wrong, and common reasons why this issue occurs
  • Suggestions for how the customer can fix the problem

Review the results, then advise the customer as needed on identified issues and possible fixes. Because there are many different types of reverse proxy software and we can't directly support them all, the solutions provided are mostly general. However, a representative on the customer side who is reasonably knowledgeable about their reverse proxy should be able to use these as a starting point for the specific steps they need to take.

Step 3: Repeat

Once the customer has made any needed changes, run the test on Dubsplat again. Continue to repeat this process until all issues have been resolved, and Dubsplat displays the Success message.

item.title: Internal: Access Full RSS Feeds for Hubs and Streams
item.description:
Objective

A customer wants to export content from Uberflip to another platform, and needs to access the unlimited RSS feed for their Hub (or individual Streams).

 

Prerequisite: Turn On the Unlimited RSS Feature

All Hubs and Streams have built-in RSS feed, but by default these are limited to 20 items. To export all content, you need to enable a beta feature that includes an unlimited number of items in the RSS feed.

  1. Log in to Uberflip Admin and open the customer's Account Overview page.
  2. Click on Edit:
  3. Click on the Beta Features tab:
  4. In the list, find the line for unlimited_rss and change the toggle switch next to it to the on (green) setting:
  5. Unlimited RSS is now enabled for the account, and the customer will be able to access full RSS feeds for their Hubs and Streams.

 

Prerequisite: Ensure RSS Includes Full Item Contents

For the purpose of exporting content, you need to make sure that the Hub's RSS feeds include the full contents of Items, not just a summary.

  1. Log in to the customer's Hub backend (via Uberflip Admin) and select the Hub to be exported.
  2. In the sidebar menu, scroll down to Hub Options and click on it to expand.
  3. Click on Advanced.
  4. In the menu on the right, scroll down to the section RSS.
  5. If it is not already checked, check the box next to Show Full Blog Article content in RSS Feeds:
  6. The change will save automatically, and the RSS feed will now include the full contents of Items.

 

Get the Full RSS Feed for a Hub

  1. Log in to the customer's Hub backend (via Uberflip Admin) and select the Hub to be exported.
  2. In the top left corner, click on (RSS) next to the Hub favicon and name:
    • Make sure to click on (RSS), not the domain of the Hub (which appears right next to it).
  3. The RSS feed for the Hub will open in a new tab, with a URL like this: https://hub.uberflip.com/h/feed.rss
  4. At the end of the URL, add: ?allitems=1, e.g. https://hub.uberflip.com/h/feed.rss?allitems=1
  5. This URL represents the RSS feed for the entire Hub, which can be used to import Hub content into another platform. Copy this URL and provide it to the customer.

Note

If the Replace Home Page with a Marketing Stream setting (Under Hub Options > Advanced) is being used, the Hub's RSS feed will include only Items that are in the selected Marketing Stream and are not hidden.

To get a Hub-level RSS feed that contains Items across all Streams, change this setting back to Latest Content (note that this will still only include non-hidden Items). Alternatively, use Stream-level RSS feeds as described below.

 

Get the Full RSS Feed for a Stream

  1. Log in to the customer's Hub backend (via Uberflip Admin) and navigate to the Hub that contains the Stream to be exported.
  2. Open the Stream to be exported. In the top right corner, click on RSS:
  3. The RSS feed for the Stream will open in a new tab, with a URL like this: https://hub.uberflip.com/streamname.rss
  4. At the end of the URL, add: ?allitems=1, e.g. https://hub.uberflip.com/streamname.rss?allitems=1
  5. This URL represents the RSS feed for the entire Stream, which can be used to import all content from this specific Stream into another platform. Copy this URL and provide it to the customer.

item.title: Internal: Hubs on Subdirectories ("Hubs on Dubs") Setup Guide
item.description:
If you are helping a customer to set up a Hub on a subdirectory (aka "Hubs on Dubs"), here are the steps you need to complete on the Uberflip side.

 

Before You Begin

  • This document is for internal use only. Please do not share it with customers or anyone else outside of Uberflip.
  • This guide is intended for Uberflippers who are helping a customer to set up a custom domain on a subdirectory. In most cases, this would be a CSM, an Onboarding Specialist, or a Solutions Engineer.

 

About This Guide

If a customer wants to host their Hub on a subdirectory of their main website domain (such as www.customer.com/hub/), we have to perform some internal setup to help them do that.

This guide describes the necessary steps. It's designed to be used together with a number of customer-facing articles which cover the same topic from the customer's perspective. These are:

  • Custom Domain: Hubs on Subdirectories Explained
    • A primer on custom domains using subdirectories that describes how they are implemented, and explains the relevant concepts and terms.
  • Custom Domain: Set up Your Hub on a Subdirectory

Set Up a Hub on a Subdirectory

Use these instructions to help get a customer set up with Hubs on Dubs. The instructions are the same for both new (pre-production) and live (production) Hubs.

These instructions are designed to complement the customer-facing instructions in the following article, so you should read it before proceeding:

  • Custom Domain: Set up Your Hub on a Subdirectory

Note

A note on the instructions below:

  • Customer Step tells you which step in the customer-facing guide the instructions correspond to.
  • Trigger Action lets you know when to start working on the step.

Step 2: Create a Custom Domain

Customer Step:

Step 3: Hand off to Uberflip to Create and Link the Custom Domain

Trigger Action:

The customer will contact you when they have set up their subdirectory.

Your Steps:

  1. Check that the customer has provided you with the following info:
    • The subdirectory URL they want to use (e.g. www.company.com/hub/)
    • Whether the domain uses HTTPS (SSL/TLS)
      • The customer does not need to provide an SSL certificate
  2. Add a new domain to the customer's account using the Domains tab on the internal Admin backend (Domains > Add subdirectory domain).
    • Include the full URL when creating the domain, including the subdirectory (e.g. http://www.company.com/hub/)
    • If the customer's main website URL does not use www, you must still include it when you create the domain, as the tool will not accept domains without it: in this case, you must subsequently open an OPS ticket to remove the www from the domain
    • Always create the domain with HTTP, even if the customer wants HTTPS (this will be changed later)
  3. Create an OPS/Infrastructure ticket in Jira to enable HTTPS/SSL on the new domain, and to add it as a secondary domain to the customer's Hub
    • Use this ticket as a template (clone to create a new ticket): https://uberflip.atlassian.net/browse/OPS-11525
      • Substitute your customer's Domain ID (see Settings > Services > Domains), URL and Hub IDs
      • Leave the Status as New
      • Leave Assignee as Unassigned
      • For Requester set your own name
    • Adding the domain as a secondary domain makes the Hub accessible on that domain for testing, while the Hub also remains accessible via the primary domain (co-branded subdomain)
    • Requesting HTTPS in the ticket is only necessary if the customer's main website uses HTTPS, otherwise leave it out

Step 5: Test the Customer's Reverse Proxy Setup

Customer Step:

Step 5: Test the Reverse Proxy Setup

Trigger Action:

The customer will notify you when they have finished configuring their reverse proxy.

Your Steps:

  1. Open Dubsplat, our internal Hubs on Dubs troubleshooting tool — you can find documentation on Dubsplat and how to use it in this article. To run a test, enter the customer's Hub URL (the subdirectory custom domain) and click on Test:
    • Pass: Dubsplat reports no failures. Proceed to the next step.
    • Fail: One or more Dubsplat tests fail. Use the failure information to troubleshoot the reverse proxy setup with the customer.
  2. Once all the Dubsplat tests pass, open the customer's Hub in Chrome and open Chrome DevTools (Chrome Options > More Tools > Developer Tools). Navigate the Hub, and use DevTools to observe what happens:
    • Pass: No script or network errors. Proceed to the next step.
    • Fail: Script or network errors are present. Work with the customer/Infrastucture Team to troubleshoot.
    • If you don't know how to use Chrome DevTools, refer to this guide.
  3. Interact with any Form CTAs and observe the results in DevTools:
    • Pass: POST requests are passed correctly by the proxy. Proceed to next step.
    • Fail: POST requests throw an error. Work with the customer/Infrastucture Team to troubleshoot.
    • This article has more info about what you are looking for with this test.
  4. When all tests pass, proceed to the next step.

 

Step 6: Client Checklist (Prior to Cutover)

  1. Generate Hub Export and check for "Canonical URLs” (referencing old domain) to see if we can supply a list of items that require updating by client
  2. [Once new domain is live] Submit new Sitemap location for the hub: https://{new-domain}/sitemap_index.xml 
  3. Update any Uberflip redirect rules (referencing old domain) to the new subdirectory location
  4. Any direct references to the (soon-to-be) old domain in MAP, Google Analytics, Google Tag Manager or any other platform (filters, variables, triggers, etc.) should be updated
  5. Uberflip's Site Engager, iFrame Embed, or Embed Stream Tiles on any external sites, you will need to regenerate/update this code once the official hub domain switches over
  6. SSL and 301 redirects will be automatically applied when we officially switch over to the new subdirectory location (no action required)
  7. Update any references to the the old domain in the header/footer. If the header/footer is in the exposed code blocks, this can be done by client; otherwise, an OB ticket will be required. Auto-301 redirects will allow the header/footer to still go to the proper location in the interim.
  8. Keep the old subdomain live and unchanged (keep pointing the CNAME to read.uberflip.com as it currently is). This will ensure that Uberflip can properly redirect all items to the new subdirectory without issue.
  9. Any server-side redirects that client might have set up on their end (if applicable) should be updated
  10. If using a subdomain as the Flipbooks domain, you can either keep it as-is (and never retire the subdomain path) or this will also need to be updated. PLEASE NOTE: Direct-to-Flipbook URLs will not be redirected by default. 

 

Step 7: Schedule and Perform the Cutover

Customer Step:

Step 6: Switch Over to the New Custom Domain

Trigger Action:

When you have confirmed that the reverse proxy has been set up correctly and is working as expected with the secondary domain.

Your Steps:

  1. Notify the customer that testing is complete, and that we can do the cutover to their live Hub when they are ready. Work with the customer to schedule and plan the cutover.
  2. When the customer is ready to proceed, open a ticket in Jira with OPS/Infrastructure to remove the custom domain as a secondary domain.
    • Use this ticket as a template (clone to create a new ticket): https://uberflip.atlassian.net/browse/OPS-11529
    • Substitute your customer's Domain ID (see Settings > Services > Domains) and URL
    • Indicate the go-live date
    • Leave the Status as New
    • Leave Assignee as Unassigned
    • For Requester set your own name
  3. Once OPS/Infrastructure has notified you that they have completed the ticket, set the custom domain as the primary domain (Hub > Hub Options > Change Hub Domain).
  4. Next, go to Account Settings > Services > Domains.
  5. On the old domain, click on Configure and set up a redirect to the new domain:
    • Under the Select your preferred behavior dropdown, choose Redirect to custom URL prefix
    • Under Specify a custom URL prefix, enter the new domain, including the subdirectory, e.g. https://www.customer.com/hub/
  6. Work with OPS/Infrastructure to ensure any canonical URLs stored in the database are updated to the new domain.
  7. Finally, open your browser and go to the customer's custom domain to test that the Hub is now loading on the new custom domain.
  8. Notify the customer that their Hub has been successfully set up on the new custom domain!
